# I. INTRODUCTION

The advent of the Information Age was sudden and abrupt, changing the world in ways Gutenberg could not have possibly imagined even in his wildest dreams.² Cyberspace is the veritable Wild West of the modern age; a largely untamed infinite wilderness of possibilities and opportunities.

This paper will explore why the Internet³ and cyberspace are so different from traditional notions of real property, and what challenges that difference presents to players on the international stage, and will rectify whether cyberspace is a new landscape deserving of its own unique law, or whether existing law is equipped to deal with the challenges of cyberspace as written. Next is a thorough exploration of what a cyber attack might be, could be, should be, and should not be, along with a discussion of why cyber attacks are not only a matter of international importance but why, in some respects, only the international community might be equipped to foster dialogue about how to deal with cyber attacks. There is also a call to action for the United Nations, with the perhaps premature admonishment that the United Nations is in the habit of addressing new and different challenges to international law. ## II. CYBERSPACE:⁴ THE NEW FRONTIER?

The United States Department of Defense defines cyberspace broadly: A global domain within the information environment consisting of the interdependent network of information technology infrastructures, including the Internet, telecommunications networks, computer systems, and embedded processors and controllers.⁵ Webopedia condenses the definition into something a bit more palatable: Cyberspace is, at its simplest, a metaphor for describing the non-physical terrain created by computer systems.⁶

Prior to considering the impact of cyberspace on international law at large, it should be noted that there are differences in levels of nefarious cyber activities, including cyber crime, cyber espionage,⁷ cyber terrorism, cyber attacks, and (the very hotly debated⁸) cyber warfare.⁹

The definition of a cyber attack is still largely inconsistent,¹⁶ and something this paper will attempt to define. But, for introductory purposes, scholars appear to agree that a cyber crime is not a cyber attack, and thus a cyber attack can at least be loosely defined by what it is not.¹⁷

The architecture of physical space is generally unmalleable; that is to say, a state cannot just unilaterally say “Let’s move this ocean,” and then do so. ## II. WHAT IS A CYBER ATTACK AND WHY SHOULD WE CARE?

In an interview with the BBC about the threat of cyber warfare, Dr. Hamadoun Toure, the head of the United Nations telecommunications agency said the “best way to win a war is to avoid it in the first place.”42 The United Nations has called on member states to talk to each other, and to pull back from the threat of cyber war.43 That sounds facially simple, but as it stands, states cannot agree even on what a cyber warfare incident is.44 Suffice it to say, states would find it difficult to agree to enter into an agreement avoiding a threat their brightest experts cannot even clearly define. However, it is clear that despite differing opinions on what cyber warfare really is, cyber security, and the breaches of cyber security are issues of the utmost importance and international law has yet to truly react to the threat cyber security poses for the international community.45

In February 2011, then-Central Intelligence Agency Director Leon Panetta warned, “The next Pearl Harbor could very well be a cyber attack.”46 William Lynn, America’s Deputy Secretary of Defense wrote, “Although cyberspace is a man-made domain, [it is] just as critical to military operations as land, sea, air and space.”47

## III. A PROPOSED DEFINITION AND ANALYTICAL FRAMEWORK

### A. DEFINING A CYBER ATTACK: A NARROWLY TAILORED APPROACH

Before international law can even remotely begin to address the threat cyber attacks and to prosecute their perpetrators, what a cyber attack is must first be succinctly defined. In an article co-authored with multiple other minds, Oona Hathaway suggested the adoption of a narrow definition of what a cyber attack is, in order to focus attention on the niche cyber warfare fills in the international community: “A cyber-attack consists of any action taken to undermine the functions of a computer network for a political or national security purpose.”⁸² This definition breaks down into easily manageable elements that properly address the specific threat posed by cyber aggression, it echoes Clausewitz’s elemental breakdown of an act of war, and it addresses the intent of the perpetrator called for in The Economist and by Solce. This definition appears to satisfy the vast majority of concerns voiced by scholars on the issue. Implicit in the term “cyber attack” is the idea that the conduct must be active to constitute an attack, whether it is active offensively or defensively.⁸³ Thus, passive conduct like scanning for viruses is filtered out of the definition at the threshold.⁸⁴

The term “cyber warfare” is controversial in and of itself. Howard Schmidt, the cybersecurity czar for the Obama administration, argued in March 2010 that "There is no cyber war. # A CYBER CHASE IN CYBER SPACE: HOW INTERNATIONAL LAW MUST ADDRESS THE THREAT OF CYBER ATTACKS OR SUFFER THE CONSEQUENCES
LEAH SHELLBERG, ESQ.
Silent enim leges inter arma. – Cicero
“For laws are silent when arms are raised.”
# I. INTRODUCTION
The advent of the Information Age was sudden and abrupt, changing the world in ways Gutenberg could not have possibly imagined even in his wildest dreams. Cyberspace is the veritable Wild West of the modern age; a largely untamed infinite wilderness of possibilities and opportunities.
This paper will explore why the Internet and cyberspace are so different from traditional notions of real property, and what challenges that difference presents to players on the international stage, and will rectify whether cyberspace is a new landscape deserving of its own unique law, or whether existing law is equipped to deal with the challenges of cyberspace as written. Next is a thorough exploration of what a cyber attack might be, could be, should be, and should not be, along with a discussion of why cyber attacks are not only a matter of international importance but why, in some respects, only the international community might be equipped to foster dialogue about how to deal with cyber attacks. There is also a call to action for the United Nations, with the perhaps premature admonishment that the United Nations is in the habit of addressing new and different challenges to international law. ## II. CYBERSPACE: THE NEW FRONTIER?
The United States Department of Defense defines cyberspace broadly: A global domain within the information environment consisting of the interdependent network of information technology infrastructures, including the Internet, telecommunications networks, computer systems, and embedded processors and controllers. Webopedia condenses the definition into something a bit more palatable: Cyberspace is, at its simplest, a metaphor for describing the non-physical terrain created by computer systems.
Prior to considering the impact of cyberspace on international law at large, it should be noted that there are differences in levels of nefarious cyber activities, including cyber crime, cyber espionage, cyber terrorism, cyber attacks, and (the very hotly debated) cyber warfare.

Classification of malicious cyber activity might derive from the intent of the perpetrator and the effects of the act. For example, cyber crime typically involves the distribution of malware, child pornography, and other crimes conducted for profit and primarily motivated by financial gain or notoriety. Cyber espionage is motivated by the desire to unearth sensitive information, and could be conducted by an individual or a group, with the goal being a pecuniary gain or a strategic advantage. Cyber terrorism is intended to influence or motivate either an audience or a government or both through threats and violence, not unlike any other act of terrorism. A cyber terrorist uses tools available in cyberspace as weapons against both cyber and physical targets.
The definition of a cyber attack is still largely inconsistent, and something this paper will attempt to define. But, for introductory purposes, scholars appear to agree that a cyber crime is not a cyber attack, and thus a cyber attack can at least be loosely defined by what it is not.
However, even once defined, there are lingering questions: should a cyber attack be considered an act of war? How would a state defend itself against such an attack? How can a state defend itself against an attack with attribution is in some cases impossible. And, at what point does a cyber attack escalate into cyber warfare?
## A. CONCERNING TERMINOLOGY

The term “cyber warfare” is controversial in and of itself. Howard Schmidt, the cybersecurity czar for the Obama administration, argued in March 2010 that "There is no cyber war. [...] I think that is a terrible metaphor and I think that is a terrible concept. There are no winners in that environment." However, Schmidt’s stance is in direct disagreement with that of Michael McConnell, the former director of national intelligence, who testified to Congress earlier in 2010 that the country was already in the midst of losing a cyber war. Meanwhile, still others argue that cyber warfare is just a new version of three activities states know all too well, and practiced for millennia: sabotage, espionage, and subversion.
The ramifications of considering cyber attacks an act of warfare are astronomical. As Schmidt stated, there are certainly reasons for considering it a terrible metaphor, and a terrible concept. But then, is an attack on a state’s cyberspace really that different from any other extraterritorial breach of sovereignty?
These issues lead to a threshold question: do computer networks pose something unique enough to require the international community to formulate new bodies of law to deal with the novel issues cyberspace and cyber attacks pose? Or, should cyber attacks be addressed in the same way as any other act of aggression and through existing international law, with no differentiation between a state’s cyberspace and real territory?

Easterbrook said, “[C]ourses should be limited to subjects that could illuminate the entire law.” The basic concept is that there is no Law of the Horse; that is to say, efforts to collect all laws involving horses and to aggregate them into one comprehensive Law of the Horse are, “doomed to be shallow and to miss unifying principles.” Thus, Easterbrook suggests the study of general rules when dealing with cyberspace and simply basic existing law to cyberspace as it is. According to Easterbrook’s theory, states should take their existing tort, contract, property law, etc., and use the broad rules encompassed in those areas of law to address cyberspace instead of fabricating new law to address cyberspace specifically, based on the presumption that creating a Law of the Horse for cyberspace will be shallow, disjointed and ultimately, futile.
Easterbrook makes three core suggestions for making this work in cyberspace: (1) Rules should be clearly defined; (2) Property rights should be created where there are none; and (3) The law should facilitate the formation of bargaining institutions. Thus, Easterbrook argues for a laissez-faire view of the internet, that we have cyberspace as it is, we should let it evolve, and we should sit back and enjoy it. Lessig’s arguments hinge on the fact that analogies to physical spaces fail when applied to cyberspace and technology. The architecture of physical space is generally unmalleable; that is to say, a state cannot just unilaterally say “Let’s move this ocean,” and then do so. Likewise, customary international law recognizes defined territory as a qualification for statehood, and with battles over land punctuating the history of mankind since 2700 B.C.E., it is evident that defining and changing territorial lines is anything but easy.
Cyberspace is different; the architecture of it is malleable, and thus, cyberspace requires its own set of rules since cyberspace essentially allows states in a sense to move mountains and to do so quickly; a notion that is difficult to analogize to the physical world. Thus, the policy behind cyberspace and cyber warfare should reflect the malleable architecture of cyberspace, meaning that cyberspace and attacks upon it should be addressed with their own separate area of law.

## II. WHAT IS A CYBER ATTACK AND WHY SHOULD WE CARE?
In an interview with the BBC about the threat of cyber warfare, Dr. Hamadoun Toure, the head of the United Nations telecommunications agency said the “best way to win a war is to avoid it in the first place.”42 The United Nations has called on member states to talk to each other, and to pull back from the threat of cyber war.43 That sounds facially simple, but as it stands, states cannot agree even on what a cyber warfare incident is.44 Suffice it to say, states would find it difficult to agree to enter into an agreement avoiding a threat their brightest experts cannot even clearly define. However, it is clear that despite differing opinions on what cyber warfare really is, cyber security, and the breaches of cyber security are issues of the utmost importance and international law has yet to truly react to the threat cyber security poses for the international community.45
In February 2011, then-Central Intelligence Agency Director Leon Panetta warned, “The next Pearl Harbor could very well be a cyber attack.”46 William Lynn, America’s Deputy Secretary of Defense wrote, “Although cyberspace is a man-made domain, [it is] just as critical to military operations as land, sea, air and space.”47
## A. DOES THIS MEAN WAR?

An offensive act has to meet certain criteria to qualify as an act of war. The United States Army’s Cyber Operations and Cyber Terrorism Handbook defines a cyber attack as: “The premeditated use of disruptive activities, or the threat thereof, against computers and/or networks, with the intention to cause harm or to further social, ideological, religious, political, or similar objectives. Or to intimidate any person in furtherance of such objectives.” A cyber attack, unlike a cyber crime, involves “an aggressive act on the part of one adversary—whether an individual, a competing organization or a rival government—against another in an ongoing struggle for hegemony in the marketplace or the political arena.”

## B. WHY ARE CYBER ATTACKS AN ISSUE OF INTERNATIONAL IMPORTANCE?
There is little debate that modern states increasingly rely on both global and domestic information structures.58 Information gathering and the disruption of communication channels have always been tools of war, and arguably, the destruction of an enemy’s communication networks could reap greater benefits for an aggressor than the destruction of weapons arsenals or supply chains.59 The more heavily a nation state relies on the Internet, especially for military and governmental infrastructures, the more tempting it becomes for states in conflict to exploit those vulnerabilities through cyber attacks.60
Perhaps the most compelling and confusing reason cyber attacks are of international concern is in the nature of how information is sent over the Internet; that is to say that when a computer sends information over the Internet that information is divided into “packets,” and those packets adopt their routes to network congestion, opting for the path of least resistance.61 Since the Internet was specifically designed to send information through the fastest route

Attribution of cyber attacks is also difficult in light of the nature of the Internet. “[G]iven that the internet is intended to be open and anonymous, the attribution of cyber attacks can be very difficult to achieve and should not be taken lightly,” said David Wu, Subcommittee Chairman of the Committee on Science and Technology’s Subcommittee on Technology and Innovation during a 2010 hearing about cyber attack attribution technology. A cyber attacker in the domain of cyberspace can “shed ties of citizenship and cross sovereign boundaries without a trace,” cloaked in veritable anonymity. ## III. A PROPOSED DEFINITION AND ANALYTICAL FRAMEWORK
### A. DEFINING A CYBER ATTACK: A NARROWLY TAILORED APPROACH
Before international law can even remotely begin to address the threat cyber attacks and to prosecute their perpetrators, what a cyber attack is must first be succinctly defined. In an article co-authored with multiple other minds, Oona Hathaway suggested the adoption of a narrow definition of what a cyber attack is, in order to focus attention on the niche cyber warfare fills in the international community: “A cyber-attack consists of any action taken to undermine the functions of a computer network for a political or national security purpose.” This definition breaks down into easily manageable elements that properly address the specific threat posed by cyber aggression, it echoes Clausewitz’s elemental breakdown of an act of war, and it addresses the intent of the perpetrator called for in The Economist and by Solce. This definition appears to satisfy the vast majority of concerns voiced by scholars on the issue. Implicit in the term “cyber attack” is the idea that the conduct must be active to constitute an attack, whether it is active offensively or defensively. Thus, passive conduct like scanning for viruses is filtered out of the definition at the threshold.

Stuxnet is a type of malware called a “worm,” which is a computer program that replicates itself to spread to other computers, usually using a network to spread itself. The worm does not need to attach itself to an existing program on any of the computers, like other kinds of malware like a computer virus does. Typically a person installs a worm by inadvertently opening an email attachment or message that contains executable scripts.
According to Symantec, Stuxnet infected Windows in its search for industrial control systems, which, in short, can be used to control the automation of industrial processes. Thus, Stuxnet could potentially control or alter how such a system operates. More specifically, Stuxnet included a special payload designed to target Siemens systems that were configured to control and monitor specific industrial processes, and different variants of the worm targeted organizations mainly in Iran between June 2009 and April 2010.

# I. INTRODUCTION
The advent of the Information Age was sudden and abrupt, changing the world in ways Gutenberg could not have possibly imagined even in his wildest dreams. Cyberspace is the veritable Wild West of the modern age; a largely untamed infinite wilderness of possibilities and opportunities.
This paper will explore why the Internet and cyberspace are so different from traditional notions of real property, and what challenges that difference presents to players on the international stage, and will rectify whether cyberspace is a new landscape deserving of its own unique law, or whether existing law is equipped to deal with the challenges of cyberspace as written. The term “cyber warfare” is controversial in and of itself. Howard Schmidt, the cybersecurity czar for the Obama administration, argued in March 2010 that "There is no cyber war. However, Schmidt’s stance is in direct disagreement with that of Michael McConnell, the former director of national intelligence, who testified to Congress earlier in 2010 that the country was already in the midst of losing a cyber war. Meanwhile, still others argue that cyber warfare is just a new version of three activities states know all too well, and practiced for millennia: sabotage, espionage, and subversion.
The ramifications of considering cyber attacks an act of warfare are astronomical. As Schmidt stated, there are certainly reasons for considering it a terrible metaphor, and a terrible concept. But then, is an attack on a state’s cyberspace really that different from any other extraterritorial breach of sovereignty?
These issues lead to a threshold question: do computer networks pose something unique enough to require the international community to formulate new bodies of law to deal with the novel issues cyberspace and cyber attacks pose? Or, should cyber attacks be addressed in the same way as any other act of aggression and through existing international law, with no differentiation between a state’s cyberspace and real territory?

## IV. Conclusion In sum, the international legal community not only should task itself with drafting the Law of the Horse, but should also welcome the challenge. While Lessig may be more correct in his analogy of the current technological landscape than Easterbrook is wrong, that does not mean that the ideas of both men cannot be reconciled. There is no reason not to take the existing international public law concerning the seas or outer space and use that as a platform on which international law could evolve and improve. There is no reason to re-invent the wheel when there is plenty of law in existence that could be tailored to fit the unique needs required by this nebulous"thing"called cyberspace.
